critique: This document is an amendment to an executive order regarding the payment of losses sustained by US government employees in foreign countries due to currency appreciation. It specifies that for employees traveling abroad but not stationed there, only the portion of their salary converted for foreign expenditure is considered for loss compensation. The order is retroactive to April 1, 1934. There's no clear indication of ideological tilt, immigration stance, expansion of executive power, federalism implications, or impact on national security vs. civil liberties. It seems primarily focused on financial regulations related to government employees. There is a very slight deregulation aspect as it limits the amount of salary that can be included in loss compensation. There is no clear indication of social inclusion or exclusion.
